title: In Syria, the fight to preserve evidence of Assad regime's crimes
summary: Several organizations are calling on the rebels not to destroy evidence of the regime's crimes, partly to help in the search for the thousands of people who disappeared in Assad's prisons.

title: Macron aims to name prime minister 'within 48 hours'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron met with party leaders on Tuesday for talks on the formation of the new government.

title: Adèle Haenel tells director Christophe Ruggia to 'just shut up' after he denies child abuse in court
summary: The French actress, who quit filmmaking after saying the industry turned a blind eye to sexual abusers, says Christophe Ruggia groomed and assaulted her when she was between 12 and 14.

title: Israel takes advantage of Syrian regime's fall to extend its control of strategic areas
summary: Claiming to aim to guarantee its own security, Israel has deployed troops beyond the UN-monitored buffer zone with Syria. While 'temporary,' according to Israel's Foreign Minister, the move raises several questions.

title: Syrian rebels name Mohammed al-Bashir head of transitional government as he calls for 'stability and calm'
summary: Mohammed al-Bashir had previously headed the rebels' so-called Salvation Government in northwest Syria.

title: 'The Paris AI summit will act against the risks and for the benefits of AI'
summary: Anne Bouverot is tasked by the Elysée Palace with organizing an AI summit in February bringing together companies, NGOs and 100 heads of state.

title: Thousands told to flee as wildfire tears through Malibu, California
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom said the state had already secured a Fire Management Assistance Grant from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to assist with the response on Tuesday.

title: In Syria, the beginnings of an evacuation of Russian bases
summary: A ballet of cargo planes discreetly takes the most important equipment to Russia, while Moscow negotiates with the new government in Damascus in the hope of maintaining a military presence in Syria.

title: Suspect in the killing of UnitedHealthcare's CEO shouts toward reporters while entering courthouse
summary: Luigi Nicholas Mangione, 26, emerged from a patrol car for his Tuesday court appearance, spun toward reporters and shouted something partly unintelligible referring to an 'insult to the intelligence of the American people' while deputies pushed him inside.

title: Crisis at Northvolt: The fall of a symbol of Sweden's green reindustrialization
summary: The bankruptcy of the Swedish battery giant casts a shadow over the economic future of northern Sweden, which had hoped for revival through the environmental transition of industry.

title: Senior Russian official confirms Assad in Russia, Syrian rescuers ask Russia to pressure him into providing secret jail maps
summary: A senior Russian official confirmed to NBC news that Bashar al-Assad was transported to Russia after rebel forces swept into Damascus on Saturday. Syria's White Helmet rescuers on Tuesday called on Russia to pressure former president Assad into providing maps of secret jails and lists of detainees as they race against time to release prisoners.

title: Biden says Trump's economic plan will be a 'disaster'
summary: Biden, on Tuesday, said US consumers would pay the price for tariffs Trump has vowed to slap on Mexico, Canada and China. Trump then announced Andrew Ferguson as the next chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Jacob Helberg as the next undersecretary of state for economic growth, energy and the environment, and Dan Bishop as deputy director for budget.

title: Le Pen and Mélenchon caught out by past support for Bashar al-Assad
summary: In recent years, both French politicians have made supportive remarks about the dictator. Marine Le Pen saw him as a bulwark against jihadism, while Jean-Luc Mélenchon was driven by visceral anti-imperialism aimed at America.

title: Europe debates fate of Syrian refugees
summary: Several countries, including France and Germany, have announced that they are suspending decisions on asylum applications from Syria. Far-right parties, meanwhile, have re-opened a political and legal debate on refugee deportation.

title: Israeli army says it has 'struck most of the strategic weapons stockpiles' in Syria
summary: An Israeli army statement said the IDF had struck Syria some 480 times in the past two days, targeting strategic military sites.

title: Israel's PM Netanyahu rejects corruption charges as 'ridiculous'
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu was in court on Tuesday, facing charges of bribery, fraud and breach of public trust in three separate cases.

title: US disburses $20 billion Ukraine loan backed by profits from Russian assets
summary: The loan, thanks to interest earned on frozen Russian assets, forms a part of the G7's aid to Ukraine.

title: Argentina rape case against French rugby players dropped
summary: An Argentine court, in the city of Mendoza, Argentina, dismissed rape charges against Hugo Auradou and Oscar Jégou, two French international rugby players. The prosecution had argued for the case to be dropped.

title: What will France's climate be like at +4°C?
summary: The national weather service has published forecasts on the temperatures and precipitation that the country is likely to experience in 2030, 2050 and 2100. These projections will serve as the basis for the national climate change adaptation plan.

title: South Korea's national police chief and Seoul's top officer detained over enforcement of martial law
summary: The development comes hours before the main liberal opposition Democratic Party submits a new motion to impeach Yoon on the martial law introduction. The party said it aims to put the motion on a floor vote on Saturday. Yoon avoided impeachment last Saturday after most governing party lawmakers boycotted a floor vote in the National Assembly.

title: 'Trump is good if not for the economy, at least for the stock market'
summary: 'Le Monde' New York correspondent Arnaud Leparmentier writes that since Trump's election, Wall Street has continued to soar, with his arrival in power expected to lead to a financial orgy worthy of the 1920s.

title: In Syria's Saydnaya prison, the shattered hopes of families of the missing
summary: Thousands of people have flocked to the prison since it was liberated, attracted by rumors that there were still prisoners in the compound's basements. On Monday night, rescue workers completed their search, revealing 'no unopened or hidden areas within the facility.'

title: The Biden administration's moral corrosion
summary: By pardoning his son Hunter before Donald Trump's inauguration, Joe Biden has flouted the principles he claimed to uphold, such as the separation of executive and judicial powers, as well as respect for the rule of law, irreparably tainting the end of his term in office.

title: The baffling success of Vienna's Christmas markets
summary: The Austrian capital hosts 14 markets in the run-up to the festive season. Tourists are expected to flock to sample a drink with a strange recipe and stroll among the stalls offering products that are not always local.

title: Ghassan Salhab: 'Lebanon has never been a nation'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the Lebanese filmmaker says his country's situation is the result of colonialism and decolonization.
